Title:
Erysiphe salicina: a cryptic species of Erysiphe sect.
Uncinula on Salix spp. in China
Keywords:
Erysiphaceae, powdery mildew, Erysiphe, Salicaceae, new
species, taxonomy
Abstract:
A cryptic species of Erysiphe sect. Uncinula on Salix
spp., a species belonging to Salix subgen. Vetrix sect. Vetrix, is
described as Erysiphe salicina based on morphological and molecular
analyses. The new species is distinctly different from E. capreae,
mainly occurring on Salix caprea and allied species of Salix subgen.
Vetrix sect. Vetrix, by having shorter conidiophores (mostly 4887 vs
80150) and fewer appendages per chasmothecium (mostly 2253 vs 50400).
The new species is genetically as well as morphologically rather similar
to E. salicis, but differs in having fewer appendages (mainly 2253 vs
2595) and asci (mainly 57 vs 515) per chasmothecium. The phylogeny of
the new species and closely related species on Populus and Salix spp.
(Salicaceae) was reconstructed and discussed using a combined alignment
of ITS and 28S rDNA sequences. The phylogenetic results demonstrated
that the sequences obtained from the ten examined collections on Salix
spp. clustered together as an independent lineage with 100% bootstrap
support, suggesting the involvement of a species of its own.
